thread.title: Jason Garrett not satisfied with Cowboys' passing game
thread.title_full: Jason Garrett not satisfied with Cowboys' passing game

title: Jason Garrett not satisfied with Cowboys' passing game
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Jason Garrett not satisfied with Cowboys' execution in passing game IRVING, Texas — Dallas Cowboys coach Jason Garrett maintained that quarterback Brandon Weeden did a “good job” overall in Sunday’s loss to the Atlanta Falcons, but said his team failed to take advantage of some opportunities on outside passes. Post to Facebook Jason Garrett not satisfied with Cowboys' execution in passing game IRVING, Texas — Dallas Cowboys coach Jason Garrett maintained that quarterback Brandon Weeden did a “good job” overall in Sunday’s loss to the Atlanta Falcons, but said his team failed to take advantage of some opportunities on outside passes. Check out this story on shreveporttimes.com: http://usat.ly/1FxUXPw Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Jason Garrett not satisfied with Cowboys' execution in passing game Eric Prisbell , USA TODAY Sports 5:08 p.m. CDT September 28, 2015 USA Today Sports' Tom Pelissero looks at what we learned in Week 3 of the NFL season, and what it means moving forward. Dallas Cowboys quarterback Brandon Weeden (3) throws a pass before the game against the Atlanta Falcons at AT&T Stadium. (Photo: Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports) 8 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
IRVING, Texas — Dallas Cowboys coach Jason Garrett maintained that quarterback Brandon Weeden did a “good job” overall in Sunday’s loss to the Atlanta Falcons, but said his team failed to take advantage of some opportunities on outside passes. 
“We will evaluate quarterback decision-making, but there were opportunities to throw the ball out there,” Garrett said Monday. “He made some different decisions, threw the ball inside and was effective.” 
Weeden completed 22 of 26 passes for 232 yards and one interception in the 39-28 loss to the Falcons. The Cowboys, who will play at the New Orleans Saints on Sunday night, will be without Tony Romo at least until the Nov. 22 game at the Miami Dolphins as he recovers from a broken left collarbone. 50 things we learned from Week 3 of the NFL season 
Throws down the field Sunday were few and far between. Weeden threw long to tight end Jason Witten, who ran a seam route, but the pass was not perfectly placed. And it appeared as if he had opportunities to throw to wide receiver Terrance Williams at times but decided not to. 
When asked if his wide receivers won enough in their individual battles with Atlanta’s defensive backs off the line of scrimmage, Garrett said, “Yeah, there were one-on-one situations out there. We weren’t efficient enough in the passing game.” 
Stephen Jones, the Cowboys executive vice president, said on KRLD-FM in Dallas on Monday that the game plan was “we could work the underneath part of their coverage and run the football. Of course, the first half we did that real well. I think you got to give the Falcons a lot of credit – they adjusted. We didn’t probably adjust as well as we needed to. We probably needed to be going to the outside group [of wide receivers] as they changed and adjusted there in the second half.” 'Joe Philbin must be fired' and other Week 3 overreactions in the NFL 
Garrett said Weeden’s second-quarter interception was a “really poor decision” and the “one real blemish” in his performance. On the subsequent drive, Atlanta scored a touchdown to cut the Cowboys’ lead to seven points. 
Garrett took exception to the notion that the Cowboys needed to specifically attack more deep down the field, citing the style of Atlanta’s defense. He said that the Falcons almost exclusively commit a lot of players to the line of scrimmage and use their cornerbacks to play high and deep, negating most big plays. 
“There were some opportunities to throw the ball outside to the outside receivers that we didn’t take full advantage of,” Garrett said. “To say we should have thrown it down the field more, I don’t know that’s accurate.” 
Follow Eric Prisbell on Twitter @EricPrisbell .
